Our mission: To develop serial innovators capable of launching and leading organizations that challenge assumed boundaries and inspire a sense of what's possible.        – A Catalyst for New Venture Creation          At the Berkley Center, we provide students with real-world, hands-on startup experiences that complement the rigorous instruction received in the classroom. And we offer alumni, faculty and staff a platform from which they can leverage their professional experience and skills to launch new ventures or accelerate the growth of existing ones.    Each year, more than 800 aspiring entrepreneurs and early-stage CEOs turn to the Berkley Center for information, guidance and startup assistance. Take a moment to explore what NYU Stern and the Berkley Center for Entrepreneurship and Innovation have to offer you, an entrepreneurial leader of tomorrow. Tisch Entertainment Leadership C: Tisch School of the Arts at NYU                           Skip to content          < back        Tisch Entertainment Leadership Conference  Event Date and Time: May 13, 2006 12:00pm - 5:00pm Location: Riese Student Lounge (Common Room), Rooms 108 and 109 New York University Alumni Reunion Weekend, Saturday, May 13th, 2006 from 12:00pm - 5:00pm. The Tisch School of the Arts Entertainment Leadership Conference is open exclusively to Tisch graduates and one guest free-of-charge. 721 Broadway, lobby. Lunch 12:00PM-1:30PM Welcome Remarks by Ryan Glass '05, Entertainment Leadership Committee Chair Keynote Address by Red Burns Chair, Interactive Telecommunications Program (ITP) 1st Panels 1:30PM-3:00PM 2nd Panels 3:30PM-5:00PM (Panel Speakers Listed Below) NYU Alumni Reunion Gala Grand Hyatt Grand Central, Empire Ballroom Park Avenue at Grand Central Terminal Cocktail Reception and Dinner 7:00PM-Midnight Remarks by Tisch Alumna, Jodi Applegate '87 Co-Host Fox5 News Good Day New York Cost for NYU Alumni Reunion Gala: $65 per person for classes of 1995-2005 $100 per person for other class years Festive Attire For more information click here: https://www.nyu.edu/alumni/weekend2006/may13.html Luncheon Speaker: Red Burns is Chair of the Interactive Telecommunications Program (ITP) in the Tisch School of the Arts at New York University. She was named Tokyo Broadcasting System Chair in 1997. Most recently, Professor Burns was a member of the 2005 Selection Committee for the Dorothy and Lillian Gish Prize, which was awarded to Peter Sellars in September. Earlier in 2005, she was added to the New York Women in Communications, Inc. Matrix Hall of Fame and in November of 2004, she was honored with a Distinguished Leadership Award for achievement in technology from the New York Hall of Science. In 2002, she was a recipient of the Chrysler Design Award. In addition, she has received a number of other awards including the 1997 Matrix Award (the first in the "New Media" category), and in 1998, the Crain's All-Stars Educator's Award, and the Mayor of New York's Award for Excellence in Science and Technology. She was also inducted into the Art Director Club's Hall of Fame in 1998 with the "Spe! cial Educator's Award." She has been listed on Richard Saul Wurman's "Who's Really Who 1000, The Most Creative Individuals in the USA 2002." Professor Burns serves as a board member for the Charles Revson Foundation and Creative Capital. She has served on the Art Director’s Club Board, the New York Times Digital Company Advisory Board, IVREA Institute (Italy), and ProBono.net Boards. She was a founding member of the Media Lab Europe Board and the Board of Directors of the New York New Media Association (NYNMA). Red Burns has served as a juror for the On-Line Journalism Awards, the National Magazine Awards, and the Webby Awards. Most recently she served on The National Design Awards committee. During the 1970's, she designed and directed a series of telecommunications projects including two-way television for and by senior citizens, telecommunications applications to serve the developmentally disabled, and one of the first Teletext field trials in the United States (at WETA in Washington, D.C.). She also created a CD-ROM on chaos theory. This innovative research center set the stage for the creation of the Inte! ractive Telecommunications Program (ITP) at NYU in 1979. She continues to research and teach. Dinner Speaker: Jodi Applegate ’87 Maurice Kanbar Institute of Film & Television Undergraduate Division Jodi Applegate returns to the Big Apple as the co-host of Good Day New York. She is a seasoned news anchor, having held principal anchor posts in New York at NBC, MSNBC and FOX in Boston. Hosting a morning show in New York is familiar ground for Jodi. She served as co-anchor of the Weekend Today Show and was a fill-in anchor on the Today Show. Jodi co-hosted Later Today, which was produced by NBC News. In addition to her duties with NBC, she was on the anchor desk for the debut of MSNBC. Prior to NBC and MSNBC, Jodi was the host of Good Morning Arizona at KTVK in Phoenix. Jodi earned a 2003 Boston/New England Emmy for her hosting and interviewing skills and an Associated Press Award for spot news reporting. She is a graduate of New York University and holds a degree in television and film. She was born in Wheeling, West Virginia and grew up in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. Jodi currently resides in the New York area. PANEL 1:30PM – 3:00PM Room 108: https://www.nyu.edu/alumni/weekend2006/registration.shtml Clicks, Capital and Copyrights: The Evolving Business of Show This panel addresses how new technologies are changing the business of entertainment. Panelists will be individuals who are currently addressing the shift in how entertainment is created, marketed, and sold to this tech-savvy generation. Some of the topics to be discussed are: * What is the future of traditional forms of entertainment production and distribution-big budget studio releases viewed in movie theaters and television series programmed by networks vs. independent video/music production and audience self-selected content and scheduling? * How is marketing and advertising shifting from television, radio and print to internet and hand-held entertainment (iPods/PSP/IPTV)? * What are the challenges in protecting creative work and ideas in the age of high-tech piracy? * What new laws are addressing intellectual property copyrights, trademarks and patents? Moderator: Nicholas Sansano is Associate Arts Professor in the Clive Davis Department of Recorded Music. Nick began his professional career at Greene Street Recording in NYC, recording and mixing for a variety of seminal hip hop artists including Public Enemy, Ice Cube, Rob Base and Run DMC. His work with the Bomb Squad production team attracted the attention of Sonic Youth, with whom he recorded and co-produced Daydream Nation and Goo, two critically acclaimed and historical alternative music recordings. He went on to record and produce the Jon Spencer Blues Explosion, The Bats, The Grifters, Grassy Knoll and Galactic, deepening his connection with alternative music. Nick's genre-crossing work has taken him around the world, and in France he found success producing multi-platinum recordings for the groups IAM, Zebda and Noir Desir, with all three groups winning Victoire de la Music awards for album of the year, all three in different genres. In all, nick has been awarded over 15 gold and/or platinum record awards in the US and Europe. His latest production is entitled This Island by the New York City based band Le Tigre, on Universal Music. Shortly after its release, Nick joined the staff of the The Clive Davis Department of Recorded Music at the Tisch School of the Arts at NYU where he is now an associate arts professor and director of the music production curriculum for the department. Nick is an accomplished keyboard player, programmer and arranger. He is graduate of the Berklee College of Music in Boston and lives in New York City with his wife and two children. Panelists: Stephanie Furgang Adwar ‘87 Maurice Kanbar Institute of Film & Television Undergraduate Division Stephanie Furgang Adwar is a founding partner of Furgang & Adwar, L.L.P. She concentrates her practice in entertainment, trademark, copyright, and unfair competition law. She is a graduate of Yeshiva University, Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law (JD, 1991) and New York University - Tisch School of Arts, Maurice Kanbar Institute of Film and Television (BFA - 1987). Ms. Adwar began her career in entertainment by working for The Gersh Agency, N.Y., Inc., DeLaurentiis Entertainment, and CBS/Fox Video in New York. She went on to produce music videos for Time Shift Video in New York. Ms. Adwar represents a wide variety of clients in the entertainment industry, including independent film productions, screenwriters, actors, performers, record labels, authors, and artists. She has lectured on entertainment law, copyright law, and trademark law at New York University - Tisch School of Arts, and lectures for the Learning Annex, the 92nd Street Y and CMJ. She is a member of the Amer! ican Bar Association - Forum on Entertainment and Sports Law, Intellectual Property Section and Litigation Section. Ms. Adwar is a member of the prestigious New York Women in Film and Television. She currently serves on the Board of Directors for The Colleagues Theatre Company, a not-for-profit theater group located in New York City. She is a member of the American Film Institute and serves on the Benefit Committee of the Newport International Film Festival. Amanda Lipitz ’02 Institute of Performing Arts Department of Drama Undergraduate Division Amanda Lipitz graduated in 2002 from Tisch School of the Arts with a B.F.A., Theater. Ms. Lipitz is the producer of the hit Broadway musical Dirty Rotten Scoundrels. Other producing credits include Modern Orthodox -Off-Broadway and the award-winning one woman show Gork! (NY Fringe –Best Solo Show) Upon graduation she received the NYU Community Connections award for her work with not-for-profits and is honored to be a member of the Deans’ Council of Tisch School of the Arts. As an actor, she has done extension animation voiceover work. While Mrs. Lipitz now resides in Manhattan with her husband Greg Smith she was born and bred in Baltimore, Maryland. Her latest project is Legally Blonde: The Musical scheduled for Broadway 2007. Michael Megalli ’98 Interactive Telecommunications Program Michael Megalli is Co-founder and Partner, Group 1066, a New York based marketing strategy consulting firm. Throughout his career, Mike has worked with companies to create strategies for selling products and services more effectively. He has worked with a wide range of clients, including: Microsoft, MasterCard, Readers' Digest, Dow Chemical, Caterpillar, and the Boston Consulting Group, among others. Before forming Group 1066, Mike worked as a Senior Consultant at the strategic branding firm Siegel & Gale. While at Siegel & Gale he was responsible for the creation and implementation of branding and internet strategies for a variety of clients. Previously, he worked at Ogilvy & Mather, developing internet strategies for the IBM e-Business campaign. He has been widely quoted and featured in publications including The New York Times, Brandweek, CNNfn, CMO Magazine, Paper, Advertising Age, Yahoo! Business News, American Demographics, and Comvergence. Mike has a master’s degree! from the Interactive Telecommunications Program at New York University and a degree in Religious Studies from Brown University. Steven Phillips ’85 Maurice Kanbar Institute of Film & Television Graduate Division Steven Phillips has been Partner and Creative Director, and now head of marketing and strategy, at MJM, a Face to Face marketing agency within the WPP Group. Steven has spent more than twenty years conceiving and staging large-scale events and experiences around the world in venues as diverse as Balinese Amphitheaters, Florida theme parks, and other more or less likely locations. One of his major tasks is the integration of mixed-media, environmental and event-based strategies into major campaigns. Steven is also a student at Columbia University’s Graduate School of Arts and Sciences at, where he’s researching how the institutionalization of marketing is not only shaping the transmission of ideas about culture, but the culture itself. PANEL 1:30PM – 3:00PM Room 109: https://www.nyu.edu/alumni/weekend2006/registration.shtml Collaborative Revolution: Artists and Technology This panel addresses how new technologies are changing the creation of the visual and performing arts and entertainment. Panelists will be leaders and innovators who have effectively used new technologies to shape their work and move their audiences. Some of the topics to be discussed are: * How do new technologies affect the creative process and the distribution of artistic work? * How are new technologies changing the audience experience-from collective to individual? * How have new technologies democratized the industry? Moderator: Clay Shirky is an Associate Professor in the Interactive Telecommunications Program, currently focusing on social software and peer-to-peer technologies, and the ways electronic networks shape the social lives of the groups that form there, and vice-versa. Clay writes extensively about the Internet, and his writings have appeared in the IEEE Computer magazine, FEED, the New York Times, the Wall Street Journal, the Harvard Business Review, and Business 2.0, among others. He also works as a consultant, and his current and former clients include Nokia, Barnes and Noble, the Markle Foundation, the BBC, and the Library of Congress. He publishes a monthly newsletter called "Networks, Economics, and Culture", and his essays are being collected into a book, to be published by O'Reilly and Associates. Clay received his B.A. from Yale University. Panelists: Tony DiSanto ’90 Maurice Kanbar Institute of Film & Television Undergraduate Division Tony DiSanto is Executive Vice President, Series Development & Animation, MTV, and Head of Programming, MTV2. In this role, Mr. DiSanto oversees production and development for long form series and animation for MTV and MTV2. Mr. DiSanto has been responsible for some of the most successful programming on MTV including Laguna Beach, Run’s House, The Andy Milonakis Show, Nick Cannon’s Wild N Out, Made, RoomRaiders, Trailer Fabulous, PoweR Girls, and many more. He is currently working on producing the next round of hit programming including The Shop, The Hills, featuring LC from Laguna Beach, 8th & Ocean, and the third season of Laguna Beach. DiSanto also served as Executive Producer and Co-Creator Total Request Live (TRL). In his former position as Senior Vice President of Production, Mr. DiSanto was responsible for overseeing the creative and physical production of MTV's video-based programming from the Times Square studios. In addition, Mr. DiSanto oversaw the production of weekend programming stunts, events and series. Prior to that position, as Vice President, Executive Producer of MTV Production, Mr. DiSanto oversaw production of programming stunts such as Spankin’ New Music Week, and created the hit series Say What? Karaoke, which ran on air for over five years, and the aforementioned TRL. Mr. DiSanto began his career as a freelance director, having worked in a variety of media, including directing music videos, home videos, and short films. During his career, he has worked with a slew of talent including Jon Stewart, Marlon Wayans, Carson Daly, Jenny McCarthy, Jimmy Kimmel, David Arquette, Countey Cox-Arquette, P. Diddy, Russell Simmons, and Quincy Jones. Holly St. Lifer ’80 Maurice Kanbar Institute of Film & Television Undergraduate Division Holly St. Lifer successfully straddles the television, publishing and internet industries as an independent writer/producer and journalist. A Tisch alumna, her television work has appeared on ESPN, WE: Women's Entertainment, MTV, VH1, Nickelodeon, Lifetime, HBO, E! and USA Networks. She writes for SELF, SHAPE, Fitness, Biography, More, Body & Soul, Oxygen, For Me and Lifetime Online. St. Lifer also teaches Feature Writing at NYU's School of Continuing and Professional Studies. David Zellerford ’02 Maurice Kanbar Institute of Film & Television Graduate Division David Zellerford received his BFA in Acting from Cornish College of the Arts in Seattle where he began his career by producing, writing and directing original work in Seattle's fringe theater community. He relocated to New York to pursue his MFA in Film from NYU's Tisch School of the Arts where he was awarded the esteemed Anheuser-Busch/Ang Lee Fellowship. The World Premiere of his thesis film and first feature-length production, Five Years (Cinemavault Releasing, 2005), garnered the 'Best Feature Film' Award at the 2002 Victoria Independent Film & Video Festival (British Columbia, Canada) and has played more than thirty festivals internationally. As a writer and producer he has had projects in development with InDigEnt (Playhouse '91) and Filbert Steps Productions (Murdering Michael Malloy). In March, 2004, he partnered with writer/director Raymond De Felitta to create Hangover Lounge, an all digital production company dedicated to digital documentary content. Their first f! eature film, 'Tis Autumn – The Search for Jackie Paris, premiered in competition in the American Documentary category at Sundance Film Festival 2006. David Zellerford lives in Brooklyn and also works as a freelance writer and producer for a large advertising agency in midtown-Manhattan. PANEL 3:30PM-5:00PM Room 108: https://www.nyu.edu/alumni/weekend2006/registration.shtml Creating Social Consciousness in the Digital Age This panel addresses new advances made in the entertainment industry that are motivated by social causes. Panelists will be leaders who have taken social issues and explored them in the context of the visual and performing arts. From the growth of the commercial documentary to new advances and methods of distributing socially relevant creative works, panelists will add new insights with regards to this changing world. Some of the topics to be discussed are: * How are artists using or avoiding technology to create and distribute socially relevant work? * How does the use of high speed communications technology to transmit current events shape those events and future governmental and NGO policies? * Does the artist have a responsibility to the subject(s) of the project beyond creating the work itself? * How are non-profit organizations effectively using new technologies to reach their constituents? Moderator: Richard Schechner is a Professor in the Institute of Performing Arts Department of Performance Studies. Professor Schechner’s major Interests are comparative performance; performance theory; experimental theatre; theories and practice of directing for the stage. His affiliations include, Editor, The Drama Review, The Journal of Performance Studies; General Editor, Worlds of Performance series; Advisory Editor, Asian Performance Journal and Journal of Ritual Studies; Artistic Director, East Coast Artists of New York; Honorary Professor, Shanghai Theatre Academy; Honorary Professor, Institute of the Arts, Havana; Emmens Professor, Ball State University, 1991-1992; Whitney Halstead Visiting Scholar, Art Institute of Chicago, 1989; Hoffman Eminent Scholar, Florida State University, 1987. Professor Schechner’s Fellowships/Honors include, 2002 Jay Dorff Lifetime Achievement Award of Performance Studies International; American Institute of Indian Studies Senior Research Fellow,! 1997; Old Dominion Fellow, Princeton University, 1993; Special Recognition Award, New England Theatre Conference, 1991; Special Award for Contribution to Theatre, Towson State University, 1991; Asian Cultural Council Fellow, 1988-1995; National Endowment for the Humanities Senior Research Fellow, 1988; Wenner-Gren Foundation for Anthropological Research, 1987; Mondello Prize, Italy, 1985; Social Science Research Council, 1982; Fulbright Senior Research Fellow, 1976; Guggenheim Fellow, 1976. Panelists: Karen Finley is a Professor in the Institute of Performing Arts Department of Performance Studies. She is best known for her riveting and visceral solo performance work, which was at the center of the Culture Wars of the 1990's. She has performed and exhibited her art at hundreds of venues, internationally. She has published numerous books, including Shock Treatment, Enough is Enough, Pooh Unplugged and A Different Kind of Intimacy, and is the editor of Aroused: A Collection of Erotic Writings. Her current book is about an imagined affair between George Bush and Martha Stewart titled George and Martha published by Verso. She has appeared in film, stage, television and has recorded numerous spoken word and musical recordings. Her next projects include subjects Laura Bush, Condolezza Rice and Terri Schiavo. Fred Ritchin is Associate Professor of Photography & Imaging at NYU's Tisch School of the Arts. He is also director of PixelPress (www.pixelpress.org), an online publication that focuses on the intersection of documentary and new media. PixelPress also collaborates with numerous humanitarian organizations (UNICEF, Human Rights Watch, Crimes of War, etc.) on projects emphasizing human rights, including a global attempt to end polio, juvenile justice, the millennium development goals, international humanitarian law. He is former picture editor of The New York Times Magazine, executive editor of Camera Arts magazine, founder of the International Center of Photography's Photojournalism and Documentary Photography educational program, and author of In Our Own Image: The Coming Revolution in Photography (1990), the first book on the digital revolution and its ethical and journalistic imperatives. The website he co-created with photographer Gilles Peress, "Bosnia: Uncertain Paths to Peace," was nominated by the New York Times in 1997 for a Pulitzer Prize in public service. Most recently he was named to the "Top 100 People in Photography" by American Photo magazine. Elizabeth Swados is an Associate Teacher in the Institute of Performing Arts Drama Department. She has composed, written, and directed over 30 theater pieces including The Trilogy, Nightclub Cantata, Runaways, Alice in Concert, Doonesbury, Rap Master Ronnie, The Haggadah, Jonah, Job, Esther, Jerusalem with Yehudah Amichai, The 49 Years, and Missionaries. She has performed at La MaMa, The Public Theater, The Manhattan Theatre Club, The Brooklyn Academy of Music, Carnegie Hall, on Broadway, Off-Broadway, and all over the world. Ms. Swados has composed music for film and television as well as a song cycle, Bible Women, which has toured the United States. She has published novels, non-fiction books, and children's books and is currently writing a memoir/text book for Faber and Faber on how to make theater with adolescents. Her newest work includes a musical theater piece about the life and work of Alfred Jarry, which premiered at the Flea Theatre in February 2005 and opens at th! e Alley Theatre in Houston in September, 2007. In Summer 2005 she created a new musical theatre piece with the cast about attending New York University and living in the city for the incoming freshmen at NYU. The 25th Anniversary Concert of Missionaries was performed at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in December 2005 and an adaptation of S. Anski's The Dybbuk, directed by Ms. Swados will be performed in April, 2006. Biography      Research Interests      Courses Taught      Academic Background      Awards & Appointments      Selected Publications                                                                                                 Biography                   Anindya Ghose is a Professor of Information, Operations and Management Sciences and a Professor of Marketing     at New York University's Leonard N. Stern School of Business. He is the co-Director of    the Center for Business Analytics at NYU Stern,     and the co-Chair of the NYU-AIG Partnership on Innovation for Global Resilience .    He is the Robert L. & Dale Atkins Rosen Faculty Fellow and a Daniel P. Paduano Fellow of Business Ethics at NYU Stern.     He has been a Visiting Associate Professor at the Wharton School of Business . He also serves as the main Scientific Advisor to 3TI China . He was recently named by Business Week    as one of the "Top 40 Professors Under 40 Worldwide" and by Analytics Week as one the "Top 200 Thought Leaders in Big Data and Business Analytics" .    His rise from assistant to full professor in 8.5 years at NYU Stern is widely regarded as one of the fastest in the history of the entire Information Systems and Marketing academic disciplines in business schools globally.         He has consulted in various capacities for Berkeley Corporation, CBS, Dataxu, Facebook, NBC Universal, OneVest, Samsung, and 3TI China, and collaborated with    Alibaba, China Mobile, Google, IBM, Indiegogo, Microsoft, Recobell, Travelocity and many other leading Fortune 500 firms on realizing business value from IT investments,   internet marketing, business analytics, mobile marketing, digital analytics, social media, and other areas.  He has published more than 75 papers in premier scientific journals and peer reviewed conferences, and has given more than 200 talks internationally.   He is a frequent keynote speaker in executive gatherings and thought leading events globally. His research has received 12 best paper awards and nominations.     He is a winner of the NSF CAREER award and has been awarded 14 grants from Google, Microsoft and several other corporations.          His research analyzes the economic consequences of the Internet on industries and markets transformed by    its shared technology infrastructure. He has worked on product reviews, reputation and rating systems, digital marketing,    sponsored search advertising, wearable technologies, mobile commerce, mobile advertising, crowdfunding, and online    markets. He also plays a senior advisory role to several start-ups in the Internet space. He has been interviewed and his research has been profiled numerous times in the  BBC, Bloomberg TV, CNBC, China Daily, The Economist, Financial Times, Fox News, Forbes, Knowledge@Wharton, Korean Broadcasting News Company, Los Angeles Times, Marketplace Radio, MSNBC, National Public Radio, NBC, Newsweek, New York Times, New York Daily, NHK Japan Broadcasting, Reuters, Time Magazine, Washington Post, Wall Street Journal, Xinhua,  and elsewhere.     He teaches courses on social media, digital marketing, business analytics and IT strategy at the undergraduate,    MBA, EMBA, MSBA, and Executive Education level in various parts of the world including the US, India, China, and South Korea.         He is on the Research Council of the Wharton Customer Analytics Institute, a faculty affiliate with the Marketing Science Institute and the Sloan Center for Internet Retailing at the University of California, Riverside.     He serves as an Associate Editor of Management Science and a Senior Editor of Information Systems Research .    Before joining NYU Stern, Dr. Ghose worked in GlaxoSmithKline, as a Product Manager in HCL-Hewlett Packard, and as a Senior E-Business Consultant with IBM. He has a B. Tech in Engineering from the Regional Engineering College (NIT) in Jalandhar, and an M.B.A in Finance, Marketing and Systems from the Indian Institute of Management, Calcutta.
